perturbation.original_text: All policies shall provide Franchisor with at least thirty (30) days' notice of cancellation or termination of coverage.
perturbation.changed_text: All policies shall provide Franchisor with at least ten (10) days' notice of cancellation or termination of coverage.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the insurance cancellation notice period to 10 days contradicts the standard 30-day notice typically required by insurance regulations, potentially leaving the Franchisor inadequately protected. This creates non-compliance.

perturbation.original_text: Developer acknowledges that it has received a complete copy of the El Pollo Loco® Franchise Disclosure Document, issuance date March 26, 2019 (Control No. 032619) at least fourteen (14) calendar days prior to the date on which this Agreement was executed by Developer or payment of any monies to the Franchisor.
perturbation.changed_text: Developer acknowledges that it has received a complete copy of the El Pollo Loco® Franchise Disclosure Document, issuance date March 26, 2019 (Control No. 032619) at least five (5) calendar days prior to the date on which this Agreement was executed by Developer or payment of any monies to the Franchisor.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the FDD review period to 5 days violates the FTC's Franchise Rule, which requires a 14-day review period, making the franchise agreement potentially unenforceable.

perturbation.original_text: In addition, Developer covenants that, except as otherwise approved in writing by the Franchisor, Developer shall not, for a continuous, uninterrupted period commencing upon the expiration, termination or assignment of this Agreement, regardless of the cause for termination, and continuing for two (2) years thereafter, either directly or indirectly, for itself, or through or on behalf of, or in conjunction with any person, partnership, corporation or other entity, own, operate, control or have any financial interest in any Competitive Business which is located or has outlets or restaurant units within the Territory.
perturbation.changed_text: In addition, Developer covenants that, except as otherwise approved in writing by the Franchisor, Developer shall not, for a continuous, uninterrupted period commencing upon the expiration, termination or assignment of this Agreement, regardless of the cause for termination, and continuing for five (5) years thereafter, either directly or indirectly, for itself, or through or on behalf of, or in conjunction with any person, partnership, corporation or other entity, own, operate, control or have any financial interest in any Competitive Business which is located or has outlets or restaurant units within the Territory.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the non-compete period to five years may be deemed unreasonable and unenforceable under California law (Business and Professions Code Section 16600), which generally prohibits non-compete agreements, especially if it unduly restricts the Developer's ability to earn a livelihood. While the contract states it is under California law, this longer duration introduces a contradiction as California courts often invalidate non-competes exceeding one year, unless narrowly tailored and justified.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600
